review_title: If you really want the PhD it's ok
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: It's helpful to reinforce your knowledge of basic subjects. You also will get a connection with the professors in the department.
cons: The pay is very low for the amount of work and there is no recognition for hard work or opportunity for a raise. Payments only sometimes continue over winter break, but not always. They don't give you any warning of how they will distribute the payments over the months Sept-May. Often you will have to grade a final exam while not being paid. The funding does not continue over the summer unless you sign up for extra classes but there are few positions available.

review_title: No boundaries, no respect for support staff
job_title: Business Presetation Specialidt in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Pay was good for the job description that I was provided with. Staff get promotions. The campus is nice. Stevens is a certified “Great Place to Work”
cons: Support staff are not given the resources that they need to succeed. Management is not helpful in removing roadblocks and setting up policies and processes to support their team’s work. They also are afraid to get buy-in for major projects and processes and pass this responsibility on to their staff. “Hardcore Mode”: Staff are assigned work and timelines that result in needing to work nights and weekends regularly. Management does not take accountability for this and blames the staff for not being efficient enough. This is not Twitter, this is not finance - if I wanted to work those kinds of hours, that’s where I’d go and make bank doing it. Staff are assigned aspects of work/projects that are above the pay grade for the position (e.g. the difference between coordinating a process vs. designing and getting buy-in for a process, even though these responsibilities are at very different levels and map to different published Stevens salary grades) The scope of work for my position was spread across four different people at my last institution. There is simply not enough labor to get the work done correctly and on time. Technical systems are outdated and/or not set up properly, in part due to rapid decisions and short timelines from senior leadership, and in part because staff turnover is so high that so much institutional and technical knowledge has been lost. Faculty do not treat support staff well. It is common to be belittled, yelled at, and mobbed and to watch this happen to your colleagues as well but not being able to do anything. It is especially bad for female staff. This is the most sexist environment that I have ever worked in. Not enough paid maternity leave. Very difficult for staff to take vacations and sick days. You’ll get approved, but you will find yourself working anyway. Frustrating work environment because of high turnover.

pros: The core engineering and science programs are first rate and it's amazing how much the departments do with so little resources sent their way.
cons:
The president seems to have good intentions but things have only gotten worse not better since Raveche was forced out. 

I only know how things seemed in IT but based on the amount of constant turnover I witnessed I imagine the other admin depts are just as bad. 

The school has become extremely top heavy with many new high salaried leadership positions created but with people who seem to have no idea what they are doing. 

There is no communication even inside departments. Initiatives are created from on top with no input from the rest of the staff. There is no focus on making sure the day to day functions of the department are running smoothly. Focus is entirely on "projects". Its obvious the only goal is create resume bullet points for top level VP's to help them land their next job.

Everyone is in constant fear of their jobs. 
Stay away. And if you are currently there leave before it is too late.

review_title: Good or Bad... Dependent on department.....
pros: The students are fantastic and most professors are great.   Some departments are well-run and would be a great place to work, while others are inconsistent.   There are great people peppered throughout Stevens, and most genuinely care about the students and mission of the university.   Benefits are okay.   Pay is reasonable for academia.
cons: The experience of working at Stevens varies greatly by department.  Not consistent throughout the university.  Lots of turnover in different departments.   A lot of restructuring.  Not enough space and growing rapidly at a pace that leading to tons of growing pains.     Not enough mingling between departments.   Each department, school, office operates in their own vacuum, no knowledge sharing.

pros:
if don't care to work hard, this is place as you can 'squeek' by and do nothing

beautiful campus but end of day who care you don't own campus and its nice look does not get you pay raise or advancement
cons:
i seen it all, from past presidents stealing money to wasteful spending

undergraduate programs are okay but most graduate program over-priced

for non-profit institution, I question as some management etc, make too much money and salary and bonus not justified this is not big corporate

the faculty votes on their own compensation and benefits, great system for faculty but admin gets the stick

they hire aggressively over past few years but when student loans dry up, only spoiled suburban American English speaking kids (mostly white lazy ones) will be able to afford this place, so school will get hit hard 

majority of staff place own interests ahead of institution and students, self preservation 101

review_title: Good job but very demanding and time consuming
pros:
A good way to offset your tuition and personal expenses.
Professors get to know you better and have a personal relationship with you. As a result you get better recommendations and direct tips for job hunting.
cons: You don't really work 20 hours a week as is advertised. Being a student means that you need the money desperately and some tend to take advantage of it. It all depends on the professor, most are very nice and logical, however others are so demanding that you can easily loose concentration of your studies.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Stevens is a wonderful place to BS around. If you are looking for a place to not rock the boat and be someone else's "assistant" this is a great place for you. On the positive note, there are actually worse places out there. People here are nice and courteous as long as you do not need anything from them.
cons: Barely anybody wants to do any work here. Staff constantly uses you for their purpose not caring about your development as a student. The equipment in here resembles James Bond movie from 1960s. If you try to initiate a project get ready to meet a fierce resistance and bunch of nonsense.

review_title: Nice school but need to make more opportunities for graduate students
pros: The location is quite good, very close to manhattan new york.  For business major students, there are more chances for them to find a job.  The science major students need to get more training on how to establish social network between people (not only on facebook).
cons: Graduate students don't have much opportunities to know how does the industry work.  They are confined within their own small circle and the school didn't provide a environment to let student know better of what they are going to face in the real world.

pros: Friendly environment, nice view of manhattan skyline from office. Enjoys the flexibility of working hours as a student. Its not same for other usual employees though.
cons: limited parking. Payroll department is not upto standard. They does mistake. You may lose a check for their mistake and won't ever get it if you do not complain by a fixed amount of days. However, recently they are trying to make payroll better by appointing a new boss there.

review_title: Comfortable atmosphere - a great place to work
job_title: Information Technology Consultant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: The IT department at Stevens provides a very comfortable atmosphere and ample room to grow within the department. Also provides a great deal of opportunity to move to positions outside of the school with high success.
cons: Currently a change in upper-management of the school, including the IT department, which often causes stress in the workplace and job insecurity.

pros:
1. University Strategic Plan was developed and President is doing a good job of ensuring the results happen
2. Benefits include free Masters tuition.
3. Employees can partake in tuition reimbursement program for their children higher education.
cons:
1.  Major cultural shift has many working in fear of their jobs
2.  President is pushing for collaboration and transparency but unfortunately paranoia  and a mentality of us against them has taken over.
3.  Higher education does not pay as well as corporate.

pros: The workload isn't too heavy and you're given plenty of responsibility. The location is great too, Hoboken is okay and you're <20 minutes from New York City by public transportation.
cons: The workload can be erratic, with periods of little work followed by lots. There is a general feeling of some disorganization too, it's not all of the professors but some are very bad at specifying what will be required in advance. The pay is also relatively low given the living costs of the area.

job_title: C++ ­ Data Structures & Algorithms | Algorithms, Teaching Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Pretty good compensation, somewhat reasonable hours, manageable workload, lots of continued practice in useful course material, will develop your communication skills greatly.
cons: Have to be available for a lot of physical office hours which many times end up going unused by the students. Not always a well organized class and have to do a lot of unnecessary work

pros:
I was working in autonomy which was perfect for me as a student.
The projects were really Interesting and I enjoyed working with this research team during my last year as a graduate student.
cons: So far I found no cons... The only things which is not really a con is that if you don't like to work by yourself don't work there because everyone is busy doing their stuffs

review_title: Could be worse, but not bad either
pros: Small departments, relatively speaking, which is good & they seem to give good leeway about pursuing research projects - assuming you have the money for it of course...
cons: Not a lot of communication between different departments unless you really go out of your way to make it happen.  kind of like working in a vacuum.

review_title: If you get in with the right people
pros: In general the hours and the vacation are fantastic. Unless there's a situation most people work 9-5.
cons: Most employees who are not deans or VP's feel taken advantage of and taken for granted. Several years of low or no raises while upper management receives nice bonuses which are not available to most of those under the VP level leaves moral low.

pros: Worked as a Resident Assistant for the Office of Residence Life. Direct management was very supportive and flexible with the staff. The people I worked with were great and knowledgeable.
cons: Some of the answers to the concerns we had weren't always straightforward or made people uneasy. Some of the expectations could be communicated in a clearer manner.

pros: Nice location with a pretty campus. Accomplished faculty and researchers. Good student experience.
cons: Chaotic mess! Three out of four deans and provost gone. Too many corporate yahoos in high-level administrative positions. They have abandoned the mission of a non-profit institution of higher learning. No opportunities for advancement. Reasonable pay, but low increases (around two percent). Too many ego monsters! No plan, structure or strategy. Major gossip culture--starting at the top.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Great quality of people. Easy access to cutting edge technology. Fixed hours. Professors don't make you work past hours. The work is not highly complicated.
cons: As a student graduate assistant, it is really tough to come up with something negative. The only thing that's a downslide is the small campus which results in not too many jobs. A very small percentage of students get to work on campus.

review_title: There is a lot of administrative nonsense but it is still a wonderful work environment.
pros: Casual but profession. I don't ever feel belittled and am definitely a valued member of the staff. I also enjoy my coworkers. I would recommend working here to most everyone. Stevens also gives wonderful benefits to full time employees.
cons: The administration is so bad it would be better served if it wasn't there. However, it does not interfere with my job on a daily basis so I can tolerate the nonsense from a distance.

review_title: A good place for independent self-starters
pros: I could explore new ways to perform my job and achieve my goals. Personal development through internal courses and external training is supported and encouraged. My immediate manager was very supportive, giving me helpful ideas at how to better perform my job. Graduate school courses are free, a nice perk.
cons: I had to spend time cultivating relationships with upper management, the deans, etc. Socializing with co-workers seemed to be an unspoken requirement as well.

pros: I worked as a course assistant for an introductory programming class. Pay was reasonable for a student employee and work did not interfere with time spent on schoolwork usually. After having one position as a course assistant, it is easy to continue/move to being a course assistant for a different class.
cons: Little recognition for work done. There are times when an influx of work appears and interferes with schoolwork, but this is rare. Not all interactions with students are always pleasant.

review_title: Not at all worth it. Not a friendly place to work at
job_title: Graduate IT Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Some free food, flexibility in timings, decent pay
cons: Unruly management, I've seen people including myself being ill-treated, humiliated and made to do labor work.

review_title: Nice place, but you need to choose a promising major and a good advisor
pros: nice town, close to Manhattan means it is convenient to find a intern in NYC. For most of time , it is relative small class (about 40 students). So you may get more attention from professors.
cons: Some majors are really difficult to find a job, like materiasl, biology.  For some classes, they hire some part-time lectures. For myself, I still like professors to give a class .

job_title: Student Staff in Jersey City, NJ
pros: very friendly working environment. The flexibility of the managers with your study schedule. Pay is good and they give enough working hours
cons: Very less part-time job opportunities. You need to really roam to every department to even get a chance for an interview.

pros: A great experience! I loved working with the Summer programs department. Everyone is very nice and easy to work with. If I could I would work full time for the department. It  really is a hidden gem in the school. They do a lot of the recruiting for admissions and deserve more recognition for their hard work.
cons: The summer programs department deserves more recognition from admissions and the school as a whole

pros: Beautiful campus and location, great students, strong education offering.  Great place to serve and make an impact for the greater good.
cons: Lack of strong leadership,  Poor HR leadership, Little interest in developing talent

review_title: Better than many other schools in the NYC Area
pros:
Small school with open door policy.
You can get things done just by shooting someone an email and being friendly.
cons: First approach with staff members is not always good, but once they get to know you everything is smoother.

pros: Nice location and a beautiful view. Manhattan is 15 minutes bus ride away.
cons: Too much politics for a university. The schools looks like a gang of different mafias. You see professor without any academic credentials and lecturers who are much more credible. In general  your progress doesn't have anything to do with your performance but everything with who is your boss and how that person is good in politics. The only motivation is maximizing the profit and education has no location in the value system.

review_title: Things do not work the way they should be working, from lab to purchase, from classrooms to machines.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Nice location, good technical institutions, smart students as well as intelligent professors. Good pay for PhD and Master students during assistantship.
cons: Lack of focus by students as well as professors. Maintanence are not done by professionals. A lot to improve on cirrucilum.

pros: Hoboken is a safe area and close to nyc. Good working environment. Good pay. People are not as nice as the south but it is a university, you can expect people to be nicer than New Yorkers. :) School is developing fast so there is tons of opportunities.
cons: I can really think of any cons during my time here which is three years.

review_title: a good place for self independent researchers
pros: Stevens is only 10 minutes far away from DT of Manhattan. So you have the opportunity to participate in professional industrial meetups and easily improve your skills in innovation and entrepreneurship.
cons: If you are a researcher, there are not many opportunities for collaborations with different teams.

review_title: Nice Job for a part time student
pros: There is always work no matter which time of the year. generally summers are busy. people are relaxed and work hard. they leave on time aswell.
cons: Work can be anything from cleaning microwave to managing expensive instruments. since its an hourly job they are more strict towards the timings. lunch break was jus 15 mins and was unpaid

review_title: Chaotic and Abusive Environment - facilities and planning
pros:
It is a lovely campus and a reputable school.
As expected, the usual higher education politics exist...if you are used to that,  its the status quo.
cons:
No standards 
Passive Agressive Management
Very poor organization
Very difficult commute if you are not VERY local to Hoboken

job_title: Student Caller in Jersey City, NJ
pros: My manager is very cool, and my colleagues are very supportive. I enjoy working in Annual Giving department. I would recommend this School for employment opportunities.
cons: As I am a international student I can only work twenty hours a week but this job offers twelve hours a week maybe this fall under the cons section other than that I like my job.

job_title: Ph D Student in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Lots of opportunities for entrepreneurship, but they do not follow up on it. Excellent drive towards patenting research. A lot of PIs are not engaged with their students.
cons: Extremely top heavy, way too much politics for such a small school. Money being frivolously spent on non essential people. Everything happens extremely slow due to lazy administration.

pros: Good view. Decent pay. Very friendly colleagues. Much autonomy as a course instructor. Great classroom equipments.
cons: Too many students in a class. The diversity of students is limited. Some students are not motivated. Some are not paying attention.

pros:
Management is open and transparent and committed to fostering an inclusive culture. 

Stevens is a place where you can continue to learn while also advancing your career.

During the pandemic they have put health and safety at the forefront of all decisions and have shown leadership that inspires confidence.
cons: I do not have an cons about working at Stevens.

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Staff and faculty are wonderful to work with. The people I've encountered are pleasant, knowledgeable and hardworking.  It's a community environment and I enjoy working here.
cons: It's a growing school with limited space and resources. There are that challenges come with that as new initiatives are being put forward. At times, leadership is resistant to change.

pros: Tremendous opportunity to expand your knowledge in several fields of study
cons: Lacking in operational/financial structure.  As a result very difficult to find important information without having to spend time searching in several areas.

review_title: pay good, students are hard to handle
pros: pays acceptable, working pressure was acceptable, you may design the course as you wish
cons: some students are hard to handle. they cannot make a question to ask but tell others that you did not answer the question.

review_title: Great co workers, not great pay
pros: Co workers are amazing, management has gotten much better. opportunities to move up within the organization. Great benefits with tuition reimbursement and activities for employers
cons: The pay isn't that great especially for the cost of living in this area.

review_title: Stevens Institute of technology - Graduate Assistant
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Pay was pretty decent.
Workload is good enough, but managers are really understanding and co-operate during the time of exams
cons: Nothing as such. Most of the things were pretty decent. I personally felt it was good option to work on-campus part time with good people.

review_title: Need pay more attentions to innovated research
pros: Very nice location and good students.
cons: A certain number of faculty members don't even conduct research at all.

pros: Friendly co-workers, smart and engaged students, and beautiful view of New York City. There is a great sense of community.
cons: Commuting to the campus is a bit of a hassle. Parking is a bit of a challenge. Office space was limited so worked in a separate building from co-workers.

pros: Good benefits, laid back environment, generous time off, room for growth within the organization.
cons: Incompetent people don't get fired, experience and opportunities for growth depend entirely on your manager.

pros: Will learn lot if you are a student employee as myself. A good place work as part time job.
cons: Some times too hard in some projects. The requirement for some projects are wide than basic knowledge.

job_title: Research Assistant in Jersey City, NJ
cons:
The salary is just average;
Sometimes the work is a little tedious.

pros: Helped a lot in understanding the American work culture
cons: Cant think of many. I wish they would take in suggestions regarding process improvement from their junior staff members or Graduate Assistants.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The management and the staff  i worked with was very co-operative and helpful
cons: Less pay , but still manageable as i was able to handle my daily expense during college

pros: Very good work environment. Friendly work colleagues.  Its a 9 to 5pm job, no extra hours (rarely at least). Good benefits such as sponsorship for a Degree or particular courses
cons: Basement AC is maxed so it can get pretty cold at times.

pros: Highly professional environment where excellence is the upper limit.
cons: Somewhat political and very mean professors who only want their department to do well and neglect the schools overall development which is unfair to the students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Very good learning experience, the management is done very well, timely notification and pay,working environment is healthy and fun.Highly recommend
cons: None so far, none so far, None so far, none so far, None so far, none so far, None so far, none so far.

review_title: Senior Assessment and Research Database Analyst
job_title: Senior Assessment & Research Database Analyst in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Unlike most institutions, Stevens would pay for you to earn a masters from any other institution as long as the degree was relevant to your current position
cons:
So much!
The systems were allll out of date when I got there. Expectations were unreasonable. Administration/management were old guards who were essentially playing house.

Terrible place to work.

review_title: Good place to work and live near NYC, nice college
pros:
Close to NYC. Nice working environment. less pressure.
Nice professional training and working opportunities on engineering.
cons:
relatively poor management, but improved recently.
Not a place for academic pursuit.

pros: light wordload, good campus, nice and polite student
cons: I wish they would take in suggestions regarding process improvement from their junior staff members or Graduate Assistants.

review_title: Great people doing great work. Really a pleasure to work here.
job_title: Computer Science Teaching Assistant in Hoboken, NJ
pros: The people are pleasant to work worth, the pay is good, and the work is enjoyable.
cons: Not much I can think of.

review_title: Great student employment opportunities to help you get experience in a field you're interested in
pros: Working as a lab assistant in media development helps me get experience while taking classes at the university
cons: Nothing bad to say about working as a student lab assistant!

review_title: I am a research assistant currently at stevens institute of technology. I am pursuing my phd's degree here.
pros: Its location is really good. It's very close to NYC, by the side of Hudson river.
cons: You don't have too many researchers in a department.

pros: Amazing manager who treats you with respect and understands and appreciates the hard work you put in your work.
cons: No Complains. If given chance I would work with the team forever but pay was less.

pros: Very good environment! Excellent courses and professors that could be a great help in our academic study and future career!

review_title: it was good and fun learning
pros: friendly environment, good to work with people, eager to make others learn new things, refreshments are provided free of cost, very good research lab

review_title: Deans asst. at school of business
pros: Sometimes you get free food.
cons: The work is too heavy for an individual. I had to undergo a back surgery due to it. Moreover there is no assurance that you will be continued. They may fire you or hire someone else without a proper notice. Don't work here. The manager is insane and moody.

job_title: Manager, Production in New York, NY
pros: they provide a good platform to learn new emerging technologies and their significant value in today`s society.

job_title: Graduate Student Life Coordinator in Hoboken, NJ

review_title: It's a good university for study

review_title: It is what you make it

pros: I enjoyed working here as a student. It wasn't stressful and I was able to do my coursework without difficulty

review_title: It's a place for not busy people,the research progress is not that much

pros: They lure apparently good people with initial compensation packages.
